qas.question: What was ASCII published as and when?
How many code positions were left unassigned for furture standardization?
When was the change to ASCII made official?
The lower case letters caused a differ in the patter, what did this cause?

answers.text: simplified case-insensitive character matching and the construction of keyboards and printers

qas.question: How many code positions were left lowercase for future standardization?
When was the change to ASCII rejected?

plausible_answers.text: simplified case-insensitive character matching and the construction of keyboards and printers

qas.question: The lower case letters caused a differ in the pattern, how did this change the vote?

plausible_answers.text: the CCITT Working Party on the New Telegraph Alphabet

qas.question: Who proposed to assign code positions without any meaning?
What task group voted its approval for the standardization of ASCII stock prices?

context: With the other special characters and control codes filled in, ASCII was published as <a0_0>ASA X3.4-1963<a0_0/>, leaving <a1_0><b4_0>28 code positions<b4_0/><a1_0/> without any assigned meaning, reserved for future standardization, and one unassigned control code.:66, 245 There was some debate at the time whether there should be more control characters rather than the lowercase alphabet.:435 The indecision did not last long: during <b5_0>May 1963<b5_0/> <b7_0>the CCITT Working Party on the New Telegraph Alphabet<b7_0/> proposed to assign lowercase characters to columns 6 and 7, and International Organization for Standardization TC 97 SC 2 voted during October to incorporate the change into its draft standard. <b8_0>The X3.2.4 task group<b8_0/> voted its approval for the change to ASCII at its <a2_0>May 1963<a2_0/> meeting. Locating the lowercase letters in columns 6 and 7 caused the characters to differ in bit pattern from the upper case by a single bit, which <a3_0><b6_0>simplified case-insensitive character matching and the construction of keyboards and printers<b6_0/><a3_0/>.
